children.text: South AL town hit by tornado, approx. 25 homes damaged or destroyed
Mobile neighborhood concerned about safety after large brawl

MOBILE, AL (WALA) FOX10 News is committed to the safety of your neighborhood.A woman who lives on McLaughlin Drive in Mobile contacted FOX10 News to alert us about what she says was a large fight in front of her home Tuesday.In that fight, she says a gun was drawn.She and other residents were also concerned about police response time. Elizabeth Kondroski lives on McLaughlin Drive and says a group of high school age boys and girls started fighting about 5:30 Tuesday afternoon in a brawl that spread in front of several houses.Kondroski said, "There was about 15 of them in that yard where that white house is, fighting I mean fist fighting, and all up and down the street." A neighbor took a picture of the fight from a distance.One woman who didn't want to be on camera says she saw a gun pulled. She said, "One guy pulled up in front of my house and pulled a gun out of his...had a gun on him, pulled it out of the car and started walking toward the crowd."No one was hurt, but Kondroski says she also saw a gun. When asked what went through her mind when saw the gun, Kondroski said, "I was worried about getting shot, worried about the stray bullets flying. Yeah, worried about my grandkids up here."  Kondroski says she called police but wished the response time had been faster. The other woman we talked to said she also called police and talked to an operator. According to her, "She said 'They're coming, ma'am, they're coming.' I said, 'Well, I have small children and this guy pulled a gun out and went toward that crowd.'  I said, 'It's scary.' "   A Mobile police spokesperson says neighbors did tell them they saw a gun. Donald Wallace says "The officers were doing the shift change at that particular time. Upon receiving the call and being dispatched to the location, officers did immediately go to the area.  We had a total number of four officers respond to that particular call.  As I said earlier, there was no one at the location at that particular time and the officers cleared from the location."  Kondroski and other neighbors say they hope there will be more police patrols in the area.
Lifeguards in Gulf Shores rescue five swimmers in last four days

GULF SHORES, AL (WALA) Stormy weather kept Gulf Shores beaches clear this morning.  After the rain cleared, folks headed to the water despite red flags warnings.  Lifeguards have done several water rescues in the last few days including two at the main beach Tuesday, April 4, 2017. The heavy morning rains made driving conditions hazardous in Gulf Shores.  The storms also chased beachgoers inside.  As the rain slowed, folks began to show up to watch the storms passing offshore.  Red flags warned beachgoers of pounding surf and rip currents.  It's been a common sight over the last few weeks, keeping lifeguards busy."It's been very busy.  We have a lot of guests in town.  Unfortunately, we have red flag conditions which is contributing to our rise in rescues," said Gulf Shores Beach Safety Director, Scott Smothers.  "Since Saturday, we've had five rescues.  We've had one resuscitation on Saturday.  I understand that gentleman's doing okay, but we do have large crowds and large surf."With that large surf comes rip currents.  Jordan Russell is in his third year as a Gulf Shores lifeguard.  He saw first-hand Tuesday how quickly a rip current can put a life in danger.  A six year-old boy was pulled away from shore into water over his head.  When his sister tried to help, they both ended up in trouble."It pulled him to where he couldn't touch and he started flailing and screaming "help" so I ran out there and then his sister ran out there about the same time to try to help him also and she got herself in trouble so I grabbed him real quick, turned around and swam back to her and then swam them both in," Russell explained.It didn't take long after the storms passed and the sun began to break through for people to go in the water despite the red flags.  Ashley Carpen was in town from Atlanta for spring with her sister and friends.  They couldn't resist going for a dip."It's okay because, like I just have to get in the water.  It's spring break," Carpen said."It's not too bad, you know what I'm saying?  As long as you're strong and you're tall, you've got no problems with that," said Carpen's friend, Brian Middleton.Russell said that attitude is what gets people in trouble most of the time."It doesn't matter how big or how strong you are or how good a swimmer you are, if you get caught in these conditions, it can pull you out.  It can even pull me out," Russell said.Red flag conditions are expected through Thursday, April 6, 2017, but those conditions are expected to improve through the weekend.   All content © 2017, WALA; Mobile, AL. NASA's Darryl Gaines brings Empowerment tour to hometown Mobile

MOBILE, AL (WALA) For more than a decade Darryl Gaines has been one of the Gulf Coast's best kept secrets. From guarding Jerry Rice, to working for NASA, Gaines is described as Mobile's modern day "Hidden Figure."Gaines returned to his hometown to talk about "21st century space exploration" with the "next generation of dreamers in Mobile. Gaines is visiting local schools, focusing on empowering future STEM (science technology engineering and math)students. The NASA Assistant Director stopped by our studio during FOX10 News at 4 p.m. to talk about his "Empowerment and Encouragement Tour". You can watch the interview in the accompanying video.Gaines, an active member of 100 Black Men of Greater Mobile, will be in Mobile through April 7.After graduating from Leflore Magnet School, Darryl Gaines earned a football scholarship to Mississippi Valley State University where he guarded teammate and "standout NFL wide receiver" Jerry Rice. From the heart of the Mississippi Delta, Darryl Gaines launched an NFL career of his own when was signed as a corner back with The Kansas City Chiefs in 1988.   Darryl Gaines is a 2017 Mississippi Valley State University Football "Hall of Fame Inductee. He's expected to return to MVSU April 8 for the induction ceremony. He is currently the President of the Houston MVSU Chapter of the Alumni Association in Houston. Gaines also serves as a member of the Board of Directors for Communities in school Bay Area in Houston, Texas. From playing in the "end zone to outer space," Darryl Gaines has been selected as NASA's Assistant to the Center Director at Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. He transitioned into the role May 2016. In this capacity, Darryl serves as a member of the Center Director's Staff responsible for policy development, staff relations, strategic planning, and management integration of technical, mission support, and communications endeavors. For more information visit:  www.darrylgainesempowers.com .
